citations.narrative:
The facility had their female sloth at a public event (Wild Birds Unlimited) on December 23, 2023. The licensees confirmed
in some of the pictures from the event that different adults and children were allowed to hold their sloth. In a few of the
pictures their sloth was stretching and reaching her neck back. In some of the photos the licensee recalled that they would
actually call from behind the camera and she would look back at the camera more as a learned behavior. While some of
the pictures might be a learned behavior or the sloth looking for her bonded caretaker, a sloth stretching its neck back and
away from someone holding it might also be stressed. Allowing young children and multiple adults hold a sloth with no
direct control of it by the license-holder can also be stressful for the sloth and increase the risk of injury to public
members. Ensure that if the sloth is in public events that she is handled in a manner that prevents any behavioral stress
or discomfort. (The licensee discussed their corrective plans and do not plan to allow the public to hold their sloth in future
events.)
***To be corrected from 2/16/2024 forward.

A wallaby has access to an area outside where the facility perimeter fence acts also as the primary fence for the wallaby.
Wood posts have been installed and the final section of the secondary fence needs to be installed. A perimeter fence is
required to help restrict animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the
animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. It must
be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the
enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence (at least 3 ft from the primary fence unless approval is
obtained from the Administrator).
Ensure to finish the remaining section of secondary fence for the wallaby's area.
***Correct by March 1, 2024.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility has enrichment and areas for birds that promote species-typical behaviors, however a written environmental
enhancement plan for the birds that is approved by the attending veterinarian has not been completed by the facility. A
written plan of enrichment for birds helps ensure that birds have adequate enrichment and veterinarian input for the bird's
environment and enrichment. Ensure to develop and document a species appropriate plan for birds' environmental
enhancement that is approved by the attending veterinarian.
***Correct by March 8, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the President and Vice President.
n

narrative:
2.131(b)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
The facility had their female sloth at a public event (Wild Birds Unlimited) on December 23, 2023. The licensees confirmed 
in some of the pictures from the event that different adults and children were allowed to hold their sloth. In a few of the 
pictures their sloth was stretching and reaching her neck back. In some of the photos the licensee recalled that they would 
actually call from behind the camera and she would look back at the camera more as a learned behavior. While some of 
the pictures might be a learned behavior or the sloth looking for her bonded caretaker, a sloth stretching its neck back and 
away from someone holding it might also be stressed. Allowing young children and multiple adults hold a sloth with no 
direct control of it by the license-holder can also be stressful for the sloth and increase the risk of injury to public 
members. Ensure that if the sloth is in public events that she is handled in a manner that prevents any behavioral stress 
or discomfort. (The licensee discussed their corrective plans and do not plan to allow the public to hold their sloth in future 
events.) 
 ***To be corrected from 2/16/2024 forward. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
A wallaby has access to an area outside where the facility perimeter fence acts also as the primary fence for the wallaby. 
Wood posts have been installed and the final section of the secondary fence needs to be installed. A perimeter fence is 
required to help restrict animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the 
animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. It must 
be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the 
enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence (at least 3 ft from the primary fence unless approval is 
obtained from the Administrator).  
Ensure to finish the remaining section of secondary fence for the wallaby's area.  
***Correct by March 1, 2024. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.

The facility has enrichment and areas for birds that promote species-typical behaviors, however a written environmental 
enhancement plan for the birds that is approved by the attending veterinarian has not been completed by the facility. A 
written plan of enrichment for birds helps ensure that birds have adequate enrichment and veterinarian input for the bird's 
environment and enrichment. Ensure to develop and document a species appropriate plan for birds' environmental 
enhancement that is approved by the attending veterinarian.  
***Correct by March 8, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the President and Vice President.
